facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 87 of 1957 appealed from judgment and decree dated December 1, 1955 of Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955 arising from judgment dated November 30, 1954 in Civil Misc. Writ No. 355 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE- JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 87 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated December 1, 1955, of the Allahabad High Court in Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955, arising out of the judgment and order dated November 30, 1954, of the said Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 355 of 1952.

facts.text: Respondent is a firm registered under the Indian Partnership Act dealing in Bullion, Gold and Silver ornaments and forward contracts in Silver Bullion at Banaras in Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a firm registered under the Indian Partnership Act dealing in Bullion, Gold and Silver ornaments and forward contracts in Silver Bullion at Banaras in the State of Uttar Pradesh.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer Banaras (appellant No. 1) assessed respondent to U.P. Sales Tax on forward transactions in Silver Bullion for assessment years 1948-49, 1949-50 and 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1948-49, 1949-50 and 1950-51 the Sales Tax Officer, Banaras, the appellant No. 1 herein assessed the respondent to U. P. Sales Tax on its forward transactions in Silver Bullion.

facts.text: Respondent deposited Rs. 150-12-0, Rs. 470-0-0 and Rs. 741-0-0 for the three years which were appropriated towards sales tax liability on May 31, 1949, October 30, 1950 and August 22, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had deposited the sums of Rs. 150- 12-0, Rs. 470-0-0 and Rs. 741-0-0 for the said three years which sums were appropriated towards the payment of the sales tax liability of the firm under the respective assessment orders passed on May 31, 1949, October 30, 1950 and August 22, 1951.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court held levy of sales tax on forward transactions ultra vires on February 27, 1952 in Messrs. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash v. Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: The levy of sales tax on forward transactions was held to be ultra vires, by the High Court of Allahabad by its judgment delivered on February 27, 1952, in Messrs. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash v. Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur

facts.text: Respondent asked for refund of sales tax amounts by letter dated July 8, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: and the respondent by its letter dated July 8, 1952, asked for a refund of the amounts of sales tax paid as aforesaid.

facts.text: Commissioner of Sales Tax U.P. (appellant No. 2) refused refund by letter dated July 19, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant No. 2, the Commissioner of Sales Tax, U. P., Lucknow, however, by his letter dated July 19, 1952, refused to refund the same.

facts.text: Respondent filed Civil Misc. Writ Petition No. 355 of 1952 in Allahabad High Court under Art. 226 for certiorari quashing assessment orders and mandamus for refund of Rs. 1,365-12-0.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereafter filed in the High Court of Allahabad the Civil Misc. Writ Petition No. 355 of 1952 under Art. 226 of the Constitution and asked for a writ of certiorari for quashing the aforesaid three assessment orders and a writ of mandamus requiring the appellants to refund the aforesaid amounts aggregating to Rs. 1,365-12-0.

facts.text: Supreme Court confirmed Allahabad High Court judgment on May 3, 1954 in Sales Tax Officer, Pilibhit v. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Allahabad High Court was confirmed by this Court on May 3, 1954, in Sales Tax Officer, Pilibhit v. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash

facts.text: Chaturvedi J. quashed assessment orders for forward contracts and issued mandamus for refund on November 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: and the writ petition aforesaid was heard by Chaturvedi J. The learned judge by an order dated November 30, 1954, quashed the said assessment orders in so far as they purported to assess the respondent in respect of forward contracts in silver and also issued a writ of mandamus directing the appellants to refund the amounts paid by the respondent.

facts.text: Appellants filed Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955 in Allahabad High Court against order dated November 30, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed a Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955 in the High Court of Allahabad against that order of the learned Judge.

facts.text: Division Bench of Allahabad High Court dismissed Special Appeal No. 18 of 1955 on December 1, 1955 holding s. 72 Indian Contract Act applies and State must refund.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the said High Court heard the said appeal on December 1, 1955. ... It accordingly dismissed the appeal with costs.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 133(1)(b) on July 30, 1956 on undertaking by Advocate-General.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants then applied for a certificate under Art. 133 1 b of the Constitution which certificate was granted by the High Court on July 30, 1956, on the Advocate- Generals giving to the Court an undertaking that the State will, in any event, pay the costs, charges and expenses incurred by or on behalf of the respondent as taxed by this Court.

facts.text: Advocate-General argued before High Court that amounts paid under mistake of law irrecoverable.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued by the Advocate-General on, behalf of the appellants that the amounts in dispute were paid by the respondent under a mistake of law and were therefore irrecoverable.

facts.text: Payments were made voluntarily without protest.

anchor.surface_text: in so far as the payments were in discharge of the liability under the U.P. Sales Tax Act and were voluntary payments without protest

facts.text: Monies received by State of U.P. had been spent away.

anchor.surface_text: inasmuch as the monies which had been received by the State of U. P. had not been retained but had been spent away by it

facts.text: Deposits made in advance in accordance with U.P. Sales Tax Rules and appropriated towards assessments.

anchor.surface_text: The amounts paid by the respondent under the U. P. Sales Tax Act in respect of the forward transactions in silver, had already been deposited by the respondent in advance in accordance with the U. P. Sales Tax Rules and were appropriated by the State of U. P.

facts.text: Both parties labouring under mistake of law at time of payment, as legal position established later.

anchor.surface_text: Both the parties were then labouring under a mistake of law, the legal position as established later on by the decision of the Allahabad High Court in Messrs. Budh Prakash Jai Prakash v. Sales Tax Officer, Kanpur subsequently confirmed by this Court

facts.text: Supreme Court heard appeal on September 23, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. September 23. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BHAGWATI J.

facts.text: Advocate-General stated in High Court appeal that respondent ought not to have proceeded under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: The Advocate-General also stated categorically that in that appeal he did not contend that the respondent ought to have proceeded for the recovery of the amount claimed otherwise than by way of a petition Under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Total amount in dispute Rs. 1,365-12-0.

anchor.surface_text: requiring the appellants to refund the aforesaid amounts aggregating to Rs. 1,365-12-0.

facts.text: Matter proceeded on basis that respondent entitled to recover via writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The whole matter had proceeded on the basis that the respondent was entitled to recover the amount claimed in the writ petition which was filed.

The High Court came to the conclusion that s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act applied to the present case and the State Government must refund the moneys unlawfully received by it from the respondent on account of Sales Tax.

The appellants then applied for a certificate under Art. 133 1 b of the Constitution which certificate was granted by the High Court on July 30, 1956, on the Advocate- Generals giving to the Court an undertaking that the State will, in any event, pay the costs, charges and expenses incurred by or on behalf of the respondent as taxed by this Court.

anchor.surface_text: Section 72 of the Indian Contract Act is in the following terms A person to whom money has been paid, or anything delivered by mistake or under coercion, must repay or return it. As will be observed the section in terms does not make any distinction between a mistake of law or a mistake of fact. The term mistake has been used without any qualification or limitation whatever and comprises within its scope a mistake of law as well as a mistake of fact.

concepts.interpretation: The word 'mistake' includes mistake of law; plain terms prevail over English common law distinctions.

issues.text: The question that arises for our determination in this appeal is whether s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act applies to the facts of the present case.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for our determination in this appeal is whether s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act applies to the facts of the present case. The learned Additional Solicitor-General appearing for the appellants tried to urge before us that the procedure laid down in the U.P. Sales Tax Act by way of appeal and or revision against the assessment orders in question ought to have been followed by the respondent and that having been done the respondent was debarred from proceeding in the civil courts for obtaining a refund of the monies paid as aforesaid.

issues.text: whether money paid under a mistake of law could not be recovered and that that was also the intendment of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 72 of the Indian Contract Act is in the following terms A person to whom money has been paid, or anything delivered by mistake or under coercion, must repay or return it. As will be observed the section in terms does not make any distinction between a mistake of law or a mistake of fact. The term mistake has been used without any qualification or limitation whatever and comprises within its scope a mistake of law as well as a mistake of fact.

issues.text: whether in a particular case be circumstances which disentitle a plaintiff by estoppel or otherwise from recovering money paid under mistake under s.72

anchor.surface_text: There may in a particular case be circumstances which disentitle a plaintiff by estoppel or otherwise. We are of opinion that this interpretation put by their Lordships of the Privy Council on s. 72 is correct. There is no warrant for ascribing any limited meaning to the word mistake as has been used therein and it is wide enough to cover not only a mistake of fact but also a mistake of law.

arguments.claim: Cannot import English law into unambiguous s.72; interpret plain statutory terms

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to observe at the outset that what we have got to consider are the plain terms of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act as enacted by the Legislature. If the terms are plain and unambiguous we cannot have resort to the position in law as it obtained in England or in other countries

arguments.claim: Privy Council in Shiba Prasad correctly interprets s.72 to include mistake of law

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this interpretation put by their Lordships of the Privy Council on s. 72 is correct. There is no warrant for ascribing any limited meaning to the word mistake as has been used therein and it is wide enough to cover not only a mistake of fact but also a mistake of law.

arguments.claim: No conflict between s.72 and ss.21/22; s.72 covers payments not legally due

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing inconsistent in enacting on the one hand that if parties enter into a contract under mistake in law that contract must stand and is enforceable, but, on the other hand, that if one party acting under mistake of law pays to another party money which is not due by contract or otherwise, that money must be repaid.

arguments.claim: Payments under ultra vires tax levy are under mistake, recoverable under s.72

holdings.text: Section 72 of the Indian Contract Act applies to the facts of the present case requiring the State to refund the sales tax paid on forward transactions under mistake of law.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for our determination in this appeal is whether s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act applies to the facts of the present case. The learned Additional Solicitor-General appearing for the appellants tried to urge before us that the procedure laid down in the U.P. Sales Tax Act by way of appeal and or revision against the assessment orders in question ought to have been followed by the respondent and that having been done the respondent was debarred from proceeding in the civil courts for obtaining a refund of the monies paid as aforesaid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payments on ultra vires levy under common mistake of law; plain terms of s72 mandate repayment irrespective of voluntariness, protest, spending by state or tax nature; affirms High Court.

holdings.text: The term 'mistake' in Section 72 includes both mistake of law and mistake of fact with no distinction made.

anchor.surface_text: Section 72 of the Indian Contract Act is in the following terms A person to whom money has been paid, or anything delivered by mistake or under coercion, must repay or return it. As will be observed the section in terms does not make any distinction between a mistake of law or a mistake of fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain and unambiguous textual reading of s72; unqualified use of 'mistake'; rejects foreign law analogies.

holdings.text: Privy Council interpretation of s72 in Shiba Prasad Singh v. Srish Chandra Nundi is correct; mistake covers law and fact.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this interpretation put by their Lordships of the Privy Council on s. 72 is correct. There is no warrant for ascribing any limited meaning to the word mistake as has been used therein and it is wide enough to cover not only a mistake of fact but also a mistake of law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses PC rejection of limited view influenced by English law or s21; harmonious with ss21/22; payment not due recoverable.

holdings.text: There may be circumstances like estoppel disentitling recovery under s72 in particular cases, but none here.

anchor.surface_text: It may be well to add that their Lordships judgment does not imply that every sum paid under mistake is recoverable, no matter what the circumstances may be. There may in a particular case be circumstances which disentitle a plaintiff by estoppel or otherwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Qualifies PC view; equitable considerations possible but not overriding plain s72; no estoppel from common mistake or conduct here.

holdings.text: Voluntary payments without protest in discharge of tax liability do not disentitle recovery under s72 if made under mistake of law.

Sales Tax Act and were voluntary payments without protest and also ii inasmuch as the monies which had been received by the State of U. P.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Irrelevant if mistake established; no textual exception for voluntary or tax payments; PC applies to taxes.

holdings.text: State spending received monies does not create estoppel or disentitle recovery under s72.

anchor.surface_text: Merely because the State of U. P. had not retained the monies paid by the respondent but had spent them away in the ordinary course of the business of the State would not make any difference to the position and under the plain terms of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: No equitable override of clear statutory duty; state cannot rely on spending; follows Mohori Bibee on equity vs statute.

holdings.text: Common mistake of law by both parties does not disentitle payer from recovery under s72.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Focus on payer's mistake that payment due when not; no blame attribution for common error; voluntary irrelevant.

holdings.text: No distinction between tax payments and other payments under s72; taxes recoverable if paid under mistake.

anchor.surface_text: No distinction can, therefore, be made in respect of a tax liability and any other liability on a plain reading of the terms of s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act, even though such a distinction has been made in America

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for our determination in this appeal is whether s. 72 of the Indian Contract Act applies to the facts of the present case. The learned Additional Solicitor-General appearing for the appellants tried to urge before us that the procedure laid down in the U.P. Sales Tax Act by way of appeal and or revision against the assessment orders in question ought to have been followed by the respondent and that having been done the respondent was debarred from proceeding in the civil courts for obtaining a refund of the monies paid as aforesaid.

anchor.surface_text: Section 72 of the Indian Contract Act is in the following terms A person to whom money has been paid, or anything delivered by mistake or under coercion, must repay or return it. As will be observed the section in terms does not make any distinction between a mistake of law or a mistake of fact.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that this interpretation put by their Lordships of the Privy Council on s. 72 is correct. There is no warrant for ascribing any limited meaning to the word mistake as has been used therein and it is wide enough to cover not only a mistake of fact but also a mistake of law.
